This is a fundamental paradox that we address by introducing a classification theory describing conditions under which neural networks can be computed by an algorithm. We also introduce a fast iterative restarted network algorithm that is stable and numerically verifies that it is optimal in terms of the number of layers needed for a given accuracy. This algorithm is a step toward the goal of deep learning in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to learn from past pandemics. One of the most frequently cited studies in this context is a classic experiment published in 1972. It is often claimed that the study’s design flaws led to its conclusion being “wrong” and that the study should be discarded. Here, we show that the study’s flaws were not only overlooked at the time but also that they are not only irrelevant to the study’s findings but also undermine the study’s conclusions.

Leprosy is a disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which infects the peripheral nerves and the mucosa of the upper respiratory tract. The disease is characterized by the formation of granulomas, which are the result of the immune system’s response to the bacteria. We sequenced the genome of a patient with leprosy from Mexico, and compared it with that of the leprosy pathogen Mycobacterium leprae. We found that the two genomes are very similar, and that the leprosy pathogen has undergone extensive reductive evolution. This suggests that the leprosy pathogen has lost many genes that are required for survival in the host, and that the disease may be caused by a different pathogen than previously thought. We also found that a new leprosy pathogen, Mycobacterium lepromatosis, is present in Mexico. This pathogen is more closely related to the leprosy pathogen than to M. lepromatosis, and may be the cause of a different form of leprosy. Our findings have important implications for understanding the evolution of leprosy and the development of new treatments. (Show more)

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also intimately related, as revealed by the study of quantum quenches. However, the entanglement dynamics is a highly nonlocal phenomenon, which makes its exact computation extremely challenging. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics can be understood in the space–time scaling limit, which is the appropriate limit for the study of thermodynamics. We provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain, which is exact in a special limit. Our work opens the way to the study of entanglement dynamics in a broad class of interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives and caused severe economic damage. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus or viral vector technology, which are not suitable for mass vaccination. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is temperature sensitive in vitro and can be grown at the permissive temperature. The vaccine is highly attenuated, resulting in mild disease in hamsters. In addition, the vaccine generates high levels of neutralizing antibodies and robust protection against lethal challenge with the wild-type virus. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. The vaccine is currently in clinical development. The results presented here provide a strong rationale for the development and use of this vaccine. This is the first report of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine. The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of human-vector interactions in the spread of infectious diseases. Our findings have implications for understanding the history of plague in Europe and the evolution of vector-borne diseases. They also have implications for the spread of COVID-19, as the vector of this disease, SARS-CoV-2, is also a human ectoparasite. Our findings suggest that the vector of COVID-19 may have been human ectoparasites during the Second Pandemic. The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in neuroscience for more than a century. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity, which is the ultimate goal of brain evolution, has been largely ignored. This study shows that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only different from that of brain size but also more complex. The evolution of brain information-processing capacity is characterized by four major shifts in the number of neurons, which are associated with the evolution of birds and mammals. These results have important implications for the study of the evolution of brain information-processing capacity and the evolution of animal cognition.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. This study provides a mechanistic basis for the observed correlation between TRAP1 expression and tumor grade in several cancers. These data also suggest that TRAP1 may be a useful target for the treatment of cancer. (Show more)

Actin filaments are the major structural elements of the cytoskeleton, and they are also the substrate on which many cellular processes, such as cell migration, take place. Actin filaments are connected together by cross-bridges, which are formed by the interaction of the actin-binding protein cofilin with the barbed end of the filament. However, the mechanism by which cofilin cuts the filament is unknown. Here, we show that the interaction of cofilin with the filament is strongly influenced by the mechanical state of the filament. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the role of actin filaments in cell migration and other processes. They also have implications for our understanding of the role of actin filaments in health and disease.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also suggest that the brain may be a target for the development of interventions to reduce the consumption of high-calorie foods. This study also shows that the effects of fructose versus glucose on brain, hormone, and appetitive responses to food cues and food-approach behavior are transient and may be reversible. Thus, the brain may be a target for the development of interventions to reduce the consumption of high-calorie foods.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The recent history of Madagascar is also reflected in the genomic diversity, which is influenced by geography and sex. The results suggest that Madagascar was settled by an already admixed population, and that the settlement happened independently from Africa and Asia. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of Madagascar, which is a unique island in the Indian Ocean. We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, which is well established in laboratory experiments. However, the results of the experiments are controversial, and there is no evidence that emotional contagion occurs in the real world. Our results suggest that people are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook, and that this influence is not limited to the short-term. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

The vast majority of RNA in the cell is not protein-coding, and noncoding RNAs can have important roles in regulating cellular processes. One of the most common modifications in coding RNAs is the addition of a sugar ring to a specific nucleotide, known as pseudouridine (Ψ). We show that the presence of Ψ in messenger RNA (mRNA) can modestly alter translation speed and the decoding of mRNA codons. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in coding regions can have important consequences for mRNA function. This study highlights the importance of considering the entire RNA sequence when studying the function of noncoding RNAs. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that higher worthwhile ratings are associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounds, and longitudinal analyses indicate that higher worthwhile ratings predict positive changes in social, economic, health, and behavioral outcomes over a 4-y period. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals relative to their terrestrial relatives is a well-known pattern in biology. We use a quantitative model of the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment to show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the aquatic environment and is not the result of a release from size constraints.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically costly diseases in the world. The human rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold, and it replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at 37 °C than at 33 °C in primary mouse airway epithelial cells. This temperature-dependent growth phenotype is dependent on the RIG-I–like receptor signaling pathway. We also show that the antiviral defense response of infected cells is less efficient at cool temperature, and that this contributes to the temperature-dependent growth phenotype. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent rhinovirus replication and may help to identify new therapeutic targets for the treatment of the common cold. (Show more)

Bacteria sense their environment using a variety of sensory systems. Here we demonstrate that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense surfaces. This mechanosensory system is required for attachment to surfaces, which in turn promotes the production of virulence factors and biofilm formation. The type IV pili-mediated surface sensing system is a unique example of a mechanochemical sensor that measures the mechanical activity of the sensor itself. This system is likely to be a common mechanism used by bacteria to sense their environment.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on aquatic ecosystems is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticide concentrations in surface waters. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This study is a first step toward a better understanding of the impact of pesticides on the global environment.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the discovery of SARS-CoV-2 in animals has raised concerns about the persistence of the virus in wildlife. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer in the United States. We found that SARS-CoV-2 RNA was detected in 33.2% of deer samples collected over a 14-mo period. Whole genome sequencing identified 12 lineages, with B.1.2 and B.1.311 accounting for ∼75% of all samples. Our findings highlight the need for a “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This study also has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and climate change. This paper examines the causes of the problem, the consequences of the dams, and the solutions that are needed. We find that the problems are caused by the industry’s focus on maximizing profits and the lack of consideration of the social and environmental costs. We also find that the industry needs to incorporate climate change into its decision-making and that the industry needs to be more transparent about the costs and benefits of its projects. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins. The exact mechanisms by which these proteins cause neuronal death and the development of neuroinflammation are not fully understood. Here, we show that neurons, which are the primary cell type affected in AD, produce a variety of potent immune factors, both at the transcript and protein levels. We demonstrate that these factors are unique to Aβ-burdened neurons, since neighboring glial cells did not express similar molecules. Thus, we propose that the accumulation of Aβ in neurons may be a significant factor in the development of AD-related neuroinflammation. This neuron-specific inflammatory response may precede the formation of amyloid plaques and tau tangles. Our findings provide insight into the complex mechanisms of AD pathogenesis and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. The earliest evidence for the use of chickens in economic activities is, however, still unknown. We present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which demonstrates that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Southern Levant as early as the fourth century B.C.E. This early evidence for the use of chickens in economic activities is supported further by a survey of the chicken bone assemblage from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. The results presented here provide evidence for the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, which was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that has been studied extensively. We find that the folding of maltose binding protein is a multistep process. The folding intermediates are native-like and are not the same for all proteins. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. This is an important step in understanding the folding process.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the predominant Np4 decapping enzyme in proteobacteria, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4-capped RNAs to accumulate to high levels. Here, we show that, in cells experiencing such stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, it is also responsible for the development of immunosuppression, which is associated with poor clinical outcomes. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression during sepsis. We found that citrulline, an amino acid that is derived from arginine, was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. The biomass of all living organisms is a fundamental quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are a key input for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and physics, where systems with no external control mechanism exhibit power-law distributions. SOC systems are characterized by a critical state, where the system is neither too slow nor too fast, and the probability distribution of the system’s activity decays as a power law. SOC systems are ubiquitous in nature, from earthquakes to neural networks, and are also of great interest in physics, where they are studied in relation to criticality. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model (cf. Turing reaction-diffusion model), requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, sensors, and energy applications. However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks into pieces. Therefore, it is difficult to use diamond in applications that require large deformation. Here, we show that diamond can be completely metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, so that its electronic bandgap fully vanishes. We also show that diamond can be completely demetallized, so that its electronic bandgap fully recovers, by applying tensile strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. They also provide a new route to the synthesis of graphite. This work is expected to promote the development of diamond-based applications.

The discovery of antimicrobial peptides in plants and animals has led to the development of a new class of plant-derived fungicides. However, the structural basis of their antifungal activity and the molecular mechanisms of action are largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of a 36-residue NCR peptide from Medicago truncatula. The structure is largely disordered and contains one α-helix and one β-sheet. The peptide exhibited potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens, including Botrytis cinerea and three Fusarium spp. It bound to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro. The peptide also breached the fungal cell wall and penetrated the cell membrane at discrete foci, followed by gradual loss of turgor, accumulation in the cytoplasm, and elevated levels in nucleoli of germlings. The results provide insights into the structural basis of antifungal activity and the mode of action of NCR peptides. The discovery of antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide against plant fungal pathogens and the identification of the molecular mechanisms of action pave the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of sex differences. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. We combined proteomics and isotopic labeling to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between male and female reproductive tracts. We show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm by providing a source of proteins that support sperm viability. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, through an A1 domain. The A1 domain is conformationally sensitive, and mutations in A1 cause bleeding disorders. We show that force application switches the A1 domain to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the effects of mutations in VWF and the bleeding disorders caused by them. The mechanism is also relevant to other proteins that bind to receptors on cells. The results are important for understanding the effects of mutations in VWF and other proteins that cause bleeding disorders. The results also have implications for understanding the effects of mutations in proteins that bind to receptors on cells.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of trillions of microorganisms that has been linked to numerous health benefits. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that live in or on humans, has been difficult to study. This study catalogs the human virome, providing a comprehensive resource for future research. The study also reveals that the human virome is highly associated with disease. This work is a significant step forward in our understanding of the human microbiome.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the Earth’s climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of dual-FOV HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This paper is expected to provide a significant contribution to the understanding of ACI.

The temperature history of the early Earth is a key factor in understanding the origin and evolution of life. The isotopic record of the paleotemperatures of the early oceans, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes derived from light-requiring prokaryotic and eukaryotic phototrophs having widely separated fossil-based divergence ages. The ancestral environmental temperatures thereby determined for these photic-zone organisms––shown in modern taxa to correlate strongly with thermostability––are inferred to reflect ancient surface-environment paleotemperatures. Our results suggest that Earth's surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We hypothesized that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The parasite exploits a number of host cell signaling pathways to facilitate invasion of the red blood cell (RBC). Here, we show that the malaria parasite’s erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) binds to glycophorin A (GPA) on the RBC surface and alters the biophysical properties of the cell membrane. We show that this leads to a reduction in the energy barrier to invasion and thus increases invasion efficiency. This study challenges our current understanding of malaria invasion and suggests that the parasite primes the host cell surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of dry air on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. They also suggest that low humidity may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza infection. Our study provides a framework for understanding the impact of environmental factors on host response

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and sentences at the top. However, this description does not capture the brain’s actual activity. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the processing of sentences is best described as a sequence of phrases, with each successive phrase being merged with the previous phrase. We also show that the brain’s activity during phrase merging is consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the brain’s language processing system.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that regulates many aspects of development. The pathway is regulated by two key components, the receptor Frizzled and the scaffold Axin. Axin is a dual-specificity phosphatase that dephosphorylates the Wnt receptor and inhibits the degradation of β-catenin, which then translocates into the nucleus and activates gene expression. We show here that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness to the canonical Wnt pathway.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes rapid vigorous eating in sated animals. We found that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and substantia nigra, suggesting that dopamine is involved in this process. We also found that LH stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of peri-LH GABA neurons, which project to the VTA and locus coeruleus. This system may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

The Amazon is losing forest at an alarming rate. The Global Forest Watch network provides a valuable tool for monitoring deforestation, but it is not always clear whether alerts are generated in time to prevent deforestation. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. This approach could be particularly effective in areas where traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols are ineffective or inhibit timely detection of and responses to deforestation.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The ears of animals are diverse in form and function, but all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which allows the spider to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. The spider also enables the flexibility to functionally adjust and regularly regenerate its external "eardrum" according to its needs. The plague bacterium Yersinia pestis has been responsible for devastating outbreaks throughout human history. The earliest Y. pestis genomes recovered from the Neolithic period have revealed key evolutionary steps that led to its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor. However, the number of reconstructed genomes from this period is too small to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia. This increased dataset enabled us to explore correlations between temporal, geographical, and genetic distance. Our results suggest a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period, a trend not observed in other pathogens for which ancient genomes are available. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (Show more)

Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. The agricultural management of grasslands and croplands has the potential to sequester carbon (C) in soil. However, the efficacy of these practices in the United States remains highly uncertain. We investigated the effects of soil health management practices on soil C storage and distribution in a 29-y-old field experiment in the North Central United States. We found that soil health management practices that incorporate perennial vegetation, such as rotational grazing, can increase soil C storage and distribution between particulate and mineral-associated organic matter. These results highlight the potential of grasslands to sequester C in the United States and the importance of managing grasslands for climate-smart agriculture. This study also highlights the importance of soil microbial traits in determining the efficacy of soil health management practices. Our results suggest that the soil microbial community is a key driver of the efficacy of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems. This study provides a framework for understanding the efficacy of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems worldwide. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the vulnerability of humans to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and cause pandemics. We then created a web tool, SpillOver, that ranks wildlife viruses based on their risk of spillover and spread in humans. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. SpillOver is a valuable resource for policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for disease prevention and control. We anticipate that SpillOver will be used to inform the development of future pandemic preparedness strategies.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinator attraction, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We identify three enzymes that are necessary or sufficient for the production of this pigment. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a molecular framework for understanding the evolution of nectar color in plants. (Show more)

We present a genome-wide analysis of a late 5th/early 6th century AD population from southern Germany. The analysis of the collective genetic ancestry of the 11 individuals indicates that men generally had ancestry that closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. Particularly striking are women with artificial skull deformations; the analysis of their collective genetic ancestry suggests an origin in southeastern Europe. In addition, functional variants revealed that they also differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Examination of the panel of functional loci also revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In an effort toward reconstructing RNA-based life in the laboratory, in vitro evolution was used to improve dramatically the activity and generality of an RNA polymerase ribozyme. The improved polymerase ribozyme can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and social well-being of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the process of exploration. We found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, can reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. This study provides a new therapeutic strategy for COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but it is also a highly toxic metal. The ability to control copper levels is therefore critical for the maintenance of cellular homeostasis. The fungal xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) has been shown to bind iron, but no copper-binding analogs have been found. Here we demonstrate that the xan BGC is capable of binding copper and that the resulting copper-binding products have antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the evolution of fungal metal homeostasis and the potential for fungal natural products to mediate interactions with competing microbes. (Show more)

The tridymitic mudstone has ∼40 wt.% crystalline and ∼60 wt.% X-ray amorphous material and a bulk composition with ∼74 wt.% SiO2 (Alpha Particle X-Ray Spectrometer analysis). Frost damage is a major threat to plant and animal survival, but the geographic distribution of frost events is poorly understood. We use a large dataset of late-spring frosts and the resistance strategies of woody plants to infer that trees are evolving cautious leaf-out strategies in regions where frost events are common, and opportunistic strategies in regions where frost events are rare. We also estimate that ∼35% of the European and ∼26% of the Asian temperate forest area, but only ∼10% of the North American, will experience increasing late-frost damage in the future. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy. Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is unclear whether Th17 cells are required for disease or merely contribute to it. We found that Th17 cells were required for the development of colitis in a Th17 transfer model. Th17 cells were able to induce colitis by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease. Understanding the mechanisms underlying the development of Th17 cells may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, but also by genetic risk factors, such as the C9orf72 hexanucleotide repeat expansion. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. This will enable high-throughput screening of drugs to identify potential treatments for ALS. The method can also be used to study the disease in other neurodegenerative diseases. This will help to accelerate ALS research and development of treatments. The method is also applicable to other neurodegenerative diseases. This is a major advance in ALS research.

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors plays an important role in pathogen colonization. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (IAFG) in the tick Ixodes scapularis, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates infection. We demonstrate that IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the vector microbiota and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The discovery of a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, adds important information about the origin of the modern avian bauplan. The presence of a fused scapulocoracoid in adult individuals independently evolved in Jinguofortisidae and Confuciusornithiformes may relate to an accelerated osteogenesis during chondrogenesis and likely formed through the heterochronic process of peramorphosis by which these basal taxa retain the scapulocoracoid of the nonavian theropod ancestors with the addition of flight-related modifications. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. The climate system is very sensitive to small changes in the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere. This is because water vapor is the dominant greenhouse gas in the atmosphere, and it is also the most variable. We show that the water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system. We estimate that the water vapor in the stratosphere increases with tropospheric temperature at a rate of 0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which is a significant contribution to the overall climate sensitivity. This feedback is positive, meaning that it amplifies the climate response to a forcing.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color in response to environmental cues. The blue-green color of some vertebrates, called chlorosis, is a less well-known phenomenon that has been observed in many species. We show that chlorosis has evolved multiple times during vertebrate evolution and that it is linked to the presence of a specific group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a pigment that is the main product of the breakdown of the blood pigment, hemoglobin. We also describe a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. Our results provide evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis and a functional diversification of a serpin. They also provide a molecular basis for the evolution of blue-green color in vertebrates. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, including breast cancer, and is associated with increased tumorigenesis and metastasis. However, the mechanisms by which hypoxia promotes breast cancer progression are not well understood. We show that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which increases NANOG mRNA levels and the percentage of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs). ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the hypoxia-inducible factors HIF-1α and HIF-2α, which also promote BCSC phenotype. NANOG mRNA methylation is reduced by ALKBH5, and NANOG mRNA methylation levels are increased in hypoxia-treated cells. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in response to hypoxia promotes BCSC phenotype. This study provides insight into the role of ALKBH5 in breast cancer progression and the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. (Show more)

The parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was so thin that it was almost transparent. The source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The Latin term abortivum in many sources has led some scholars to suggest that fetal calves or sheep skins were used. Others have argued that it would not be possible to sustain herds if so many pocket Bibles were produced from fetal skins, arguing instead for unexpected alternatives, such as rabbit. Here, we report a simple and objective method using standard conservation treatments to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals. The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical to understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds in China. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. This age model will also be critical for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for neutralizing antibodies and vaccines. We use cryo-electron microscopy to determine the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor-binding domain of ACE2. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein is associated with a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. This study provides a structural basis for the increased infectivity of the D614G mutant virus. Our findings also suggest that antibodies targeting the D614G mutant spike may be less effective. This may be an important consideration in the development of vaccines and therapeutics.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. The chemical hardness and electronegativity are two central properties of atoms, which are widely used in chemistry. Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in some regions, but the global-scale effects are uncertain. We show that changes in human demography can reduce fire activity, which could offset some of the warming caused by greenhouse gas emissions. However, we also find that climate change can reduce fire activity, which could exacerbate warming. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need to consider fire in climate change mitigation strategies.

The gut microbiota is a critical component of the health of many animals, including humans. The mechanisms by which animals regulate the composition of their gut microbiota are largely unknown. We show here that the symbiotic bacterium of the squid Euprymna scolopes provides a single glycan to its host just before dusk, when the host immune cells migrate into the symbiotic organ. The glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which uses the resulting carbon to maintain a stable symbiosis. This glycan-catabolizing activity of the host is also required for the periodic acidification of the symbiotic organ, which enhances the activity of the symbiont. We propose that this strategy is used by animals to regulate the composition of their gut microbiota. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify latent patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use a sparse representation of an embedding space to identify a set of latent topics that can be interpreted as latent topics. We can also infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). The NVDRS summarizes violent death incidents with structured variables and unstructured narratives. We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains and is likely to be useful for many applications.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important prey for many species of fish, seabirds, and marine mammals. Mass mortality events of these species have been linked to the introduction of pathogens. Here, we present evidence that a densovirus is responsible for the recent mass mortality of sea stars (asteroid species) in the Northeast Pacific. This is the first report of a virus causing mass mortality of sea stars. The discovery of this virus has important implications for understanding the role of viruses in the marine ecosystem.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a devastating disease with a poor prognosis. The identification of targets for therapy is therefore of great importance. We show here that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We further show that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects. Finally, we generated an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The results also provide evidence that antibody-mediated killing of leukemic stem cells is a feasible approach for the treatment of AML. This approach may be applicable to other diseases in which leukemic stem cells are responsible for the maintenance of the disease. The results also provide evidence that IL1RAP can be targeted with an antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south. We find that Madagascar is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The recent demographic growth happened in a sex-biased way, with a higher contribution of African ancestry from men to women. Finally, we find that the genetic structure is influenced by geography, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a nonrandom way. These results help to understand the history of Madagascar and the origin of its unique genomic diversity. They also provide a framework to study the impact of human activities on the island.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. Language processing involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. This ability is thought to be supported by elevated neural activity. However, other work has argued that short-term synaptic facilitation can also contribute to memory. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that changes in the strength of synaptic connections can be mimicked by changes in the strength of intrinsic connections. This mechanism is based on the idea that information is stored in the dynamics of the system rather than in the membrane potential. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a powerful tool for understanding the evolution of the eukaryotic cell. The molecular signature of the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is still unclear. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. This model can be applied to other transitions in the evolution of genomes. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of cities to climate change. We use a high-resolution climate model to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of the 2015–2017 Cape Town drought by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in southwestern South Africa to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is important for informing drought risk management and climate change adaptation strategies in the region. (Abridged)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The first known quasicrystal, found in the mineral naturalium, was discovered in 1984. Since then, more than 100 quasicrystal-forming systems have been discovered, including the first anthropogenic quasicrystals, found in the 1990s. The discovery of anthropogenic quasicrystals in the 1990s and 2000s has led to the development of a new field of research, the study of anthropogenic materials. This article describes the discovery of the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal, found in a sample of red trinitite from the Trinity test of the first nuclear bomb. The discovery of this material provides a link between the discovery of the first anthropogenic quasicrystal and the discovery of the first nuclear bomb. The discovery of this material also provides a link between the discovery of the first nuclear bomb and the end of World War II.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the diiron enzyme. These data delineate three classes of diiron cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Show more)

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a broad phenotypic spectrum. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. As an alternative approach, extensive efforts have been devoted to identifying the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes to facilitate mapping out causal paths. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. Our results indicate that behavioral flexibility is a converging target of the autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for understanding the etiology of autism and for developing therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The store-operated Ca2+ (SO) channel is a key regulator of cellular functions, including gene expression, cell growth and differentiation, and Ca2+ homeostasis. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated SO channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the SO channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. The proteins that form inclusions are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, they are a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a consequence of the unique cellular environment of motor neurons, which are highly specialized for the transmission of motor commands. The metastable state may also be a consequence of the unique protein interactions of these proteins in motor neurons. This study suggests that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons. Thus, the metastable state of these proteins may be a common feature of neurodegenerative diseases. This study also suggests that the unique cellular environment of motor neurons may be a key factor in the formation of inclusion bodies in ALS. This study provides a new perspective on the formation of inclusion bodies in ALS.

The origin of the flowering plants is a major evolutionary event that has been poorly understood. The research presented here centers on Montsechia vidalii, a fossil plant from the early Cretaceous that has been poorly understood in the past. The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) from Eurasia and Greenland. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya. We also find that the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. These results emphasize the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising, and it is rising because of climate change. This study provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is consistent with the rate of sea level rise estimated by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) in its Fifth Assessment Report. This study also provides a new estimate of the acceleration of sea level rise, which is consistent with the acceleration of sea level rise estimated by the IPCC. These results provide a more accurate estimate of the rate of sea level rise and the acceleration of sea level rise, which are important for understanding the impact of sea level rise on coastal communities and for developing adaptation strategies.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a more general erosion of working-class life for all adults.

The ability to characterize the structure and dynamics of enzyme intermediates is a key goal of structural biology. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. This integrated approach provides a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of the intermediate, including the location of the protonation states of the ionizable sites on the cofactor, substrate, and catalytic side chains as well as the location and orientation of crystallographic waters within the active site. This work highlights the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into the chemistry of enzyme active sites. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe, often fatal, disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate of the disease underscores the need for effective antiviral therapies. We tested the antiviral activity of remdesivir, a nucleotide analog that is effective against SARS-CoV, in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. Remdesivir treatment was highly effective in preventing disease, and in reducing virus replication and lung pathology. These data support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection. The efficacy of remdesivir against the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV is also supported. This compound may be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the recently emerged severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2. This compound may also be considered for other RNA viruses, including influenza. The availability of effective antiviral therapies is critical to reducing the impact of emerging viral diseases.

The gut microbiota is a critical component of the health of many animals, including humans. The mechanisms by which animals regulate the composition of their gut microbiota are largely unknown. We show here that the symbiotic bacterium of the squid Euprymna scolopes provides a single glycan to its host just before dusk, when the host immune cells migrate into the symbiotic organ. The glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which uses the resulting carbon to maintain a stable symbiosis. This glycan-catabolizing activity of the host is also required for the periodic acidification of the symbiotic organ, which enhances the activity of the symbiont. The food system is a major driver of environmental degradation and a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food choices of the global population are a key lever for reducing these impacts. However, the food environment in which people make their choices is highly complex, with many competing influences. This complexity makes it difficult to identify and implement effective interventions to promote more sustainable diets. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering environment can have a large impact on meal selection behavior. This approach could be used to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals served in a wide range of catering environments, including schools, hospitals, and workplaces. Our results suggest that it may be possible to achieve a 70% reduction in meat consumption in the UK by simply increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals served in catering outlets. This would have important benefits for the environment and population health.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a widespread call for expanding vote-by-mail programs in the United States. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of universal vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and overall turnout. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. We also find that vote-by-mail does not appear to increase the likelihood of voter fraud. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic. They also suggest that the United States should not rush to expand vote-by-mail programs. Instead, policymakers should carefully consider the evidence and implement vote-by-mail programs in a limited number of counties or states. This would allow policymakers to learn from the experience of implementing vote-by-mail programs before expanding them

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Influenza A viruses are responsible for an annual influenza epidemic and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of influenza A viruses is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates genomic packaging. The selective packaging of viral RNA into virions is a fundamental process in all viruses, but the molecular details of this process are unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This work provides insights into the molecular details of the selective packaging of viral RNA into virions. (Show more)

Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the prevention of atherogenesis. The findings of this study may also be applicable to other cell types and tissues that are regulated by YAP/TAZ. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire in the United States, and the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the geographic and seasonal extent of human-started wildfires relative to lightning-started wildfires. We find that human-started wildfires have greatly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire should focus on reducing the number of human-started wildfires.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that physical improvements are more likely to occur in neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults and that are more likely to be physically attractive. These results have implications for urban planning and for the design of computer vision methods for urban studies.

Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We estimate the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques.
