Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae, resulting in the loss of the majority of the coral’s photosynthetic capacity. The underlying mechanisms are still poorly understood. Here, we show that altered nutrient cycling during heat stress is a primary driver of the functional breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This work also highlights the importance of nutrient cycling in the stability of the coral holobiont. Understanding the mechanisms that maintain the stability of the coral–algal symbiosis is crucial for predicting the fate of coral reefs under climate change. (Show more)

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier to the environment and a hub for communication with the microbiome. In this study, we investigate the consequences of tumorigenesis on the microbiome and the microbiome on tumorigenesis. We show that upon loss of BMP signaling, tumors lead to aberrant activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, followed by intestinal barrier dysfunction and commensal imbalance. In turn, the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. We find that inhibiting JNK signaling or depletion of the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismic lifespan extension. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work provides insights into the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Breast cancer is the most common malignancy in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but resistance to chemotherapy is common. We found that treatment of breast cancer cells with chemotherapy enhanced the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1. ROR1 expression was associated with the expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). ROR1 expression also enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. The start of accelerated deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere (SH) is often ascribed to a sudden poleward shift in the SH westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that a unique volcanic eruption series, with fallout >2,800 km from the source, occurred exactly at the start of accelerated deglaciation in the SH. Extensive fallout from these massive eruptions has been found in the SH, including in the West Antarctic Ice Sheet Divide, Byrd, and other ice cores. The eruptions led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which plausibly linked the Mount Takahe eruptions to the onset of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation ∼17.7 ka. This study provides a unique example of how volcanic eruptions can impact climate and the atmosphere at timescales relevant to the origin of the atmosphere. It also provides a new perspective on the role of stratospheric ozone depletion in the evolution of the early atmosphere. This study also highlights the importance of volcanic eruptions in the early Earth system. Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. Our results underscore the high stakes for improving fishery management.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This DLK-independent regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of the neuron’s sensory dendrite and is enhanced by disrupting calcium signaling or elevating cAMP. These findings suggest that DLK-independent regeneration is a powerful platform for gene discovery in the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. Moreover, they suggest that DLK-independent regeneration may be a useful model for studying endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the adult nervous system. These findings may also have implications for understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying the mammalian CNS’s ability to regenerate after injury.

Recombination is essential for the generation of genetic diversity in populations and species. In eukaryotes, recombination is initiated by the binding of proteins to specific DNA sequences. In this study, we use a population of wild monkeyflowers to map the locations of these binding sites. We find that the distribution of binding sites is strikingly similar to that of recombination hotspots, suggesting that the initiation of recombination in eukaryotes may be conserved.

The resting brain is a complex system, with a large number of interacting networks. The identification of these networks is a major challenge in neuroscience. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant metabolic RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease (PD), this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. These results illustrate the potential of metabolic imaging to provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of eukaryotic messenger RNA (mRNA). It is essential for efficient translation and is also involved in mRNA export and stability. The recent discovery of 5′ NAD-RNA in bacteria suggests that NAD+ may play a role in mRNA metabolism. We show that 5′ NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. This 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate mRNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This discovery expands the range of modifications that can be found at the 5′ end of eukaryotic mRNA. It also suggests that NAD+ may play a role in mRNA metabolism in eukaryotes.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The etiology of this disorder is multifactorial, but the role of the gut microbiota in the development of alcohol dependence has been recently suggested. The aim of the present study was to investigate the presence of gut leakiness in alcohol-dependent subjects and to explore the relationship between gut permeability, gut microbiota composition, and psychological symptoms. We found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also suggests that gut dysfunction may be involved in the development of psychological symptoms in alcohol dependence. This hypothesis needs to be confirmed in future studies. (Show more)

The production of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) is a key feature of fruit ripening. These VOCs contribute to the overall aroma of the fruit and are important for the flavor of the final product. The biosynthesis of these VOCs is not well understood, and the contribution of nitrogenous VOCs to the overall aroma of tomato fruit is unknown. Here, we identify a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous VOCs in tomato fruit. We show that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce the VOCs. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of VOCs in tomato fruit and will be of interest to researchers studying the biosynthesis of VOCs in other fruit species. This work also provides a model for understanding the biosynthesis of VOCs in other species of the tomato clade. (For review, see main text.)

Biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we use high-throughput experiments to investigate how changes in temperature affect the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. We found that changes in temperature systematically altered the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures departed from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increased, meaning that more species were required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for our ability to predict the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning. They also highlight the importance of considering the role of species interactions in mediating the impacts of environmental change. This is particularly important for understanding the potential for biodiversity loss to exacerbate the impacts of climate change.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to encode different aspects of the environment. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC is still poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of MEC neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which encode the spatial location of the animal in the environment, are anatomically distinct from other cell types, which suggests that they might form a separate network. These results provide a detailed view of the organization of MEC neurons in vivo and will be useful for future studies aimed at understanding the neural basis of navigation.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We demonstrate that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This work provides a unique view of the organization of the dopamine-containing nigral system. It also suggests that striosomes may be important in the control of movement and motivation. This study is important because it provides a detailed view of the organization of the dopamine-containing nigral system and suggests that striosomes may be important in the control of movement and motivation.

We all feel connected to others, but how do we know when we’re feeling connected to someone? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Finally, we demonstrate that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected: Conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate and are characterized by unique electrophysiological properties. SAN dysfunction is associated with a variety of cardiovascular diseases. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is selectively expressed in SANCs and plays a critical role in SAN function. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores of SANCs and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. Moreover, STIM1 influenced SAN function by regulating ionic fluxes in SANCs, including activation of a store-operated Ca2+ current, a reduction in L-type Ca2+ current, and enhancing the activities of Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. Although the function of Si in plant physiology has been well documented, its beneficial effects on plant resistance against insect herbivory have been less well studied. In this study, we demonstrate that Si pretreatment enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest, and that this effect is mediated by jasmonic acid (JA), a key signaling molecule in plant defense responses. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact synergistically to promote rice resistance against insect herbivory. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense against insect herbivory. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is still poorly understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, an enzyme involved in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism and for the treatment of phenylketonuria. They also suggest that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity may be a target for the treatment of inflammatory diseases. This study also provides a new model for the study of the role of ether lipid metabolism in macrophage activation. This model can be used to study the role of ether lipid metabolism in other cell types. It can also be used to study the role of alkylglycerol monooxygenase in other diseases.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. This ability is thought to be supported by elevated neural activity. However, other work has suggested that short-term synaptic facilitation can also contribute to memory. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that changes in the strength of synaptic connections can alter the firing rates of neurons and that these changes can be used to store information. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. The delivery of functional biomolecules such as siRNA to plants is even more challenging. Here, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver siRNA to plants and that the size, shape, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important for the delivery efficiency. We also show that the delivery of biomolecules to plants is dependent on the DNA nanostructure geometry. This work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization. This work also provides a framework for the design of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. (Show more)

Nutrient pollution from small streams is a growing concern for coastal ecosystems worldwide. However, the relative importance of small streams in delivering nutrients to lakes has not been quantified. We used a snapshot of nutrient inputs from nearly all tributaries of Lake Michigan to determine how land cover and dams alter nutrient inputs across watershed sizes. Our findings reveal that small streams can be a significant source of nutrients to lakes, especially in nearshore areas. Although they represent only a modest proportion of lake-wide loads, expanding nutrient management efforts to address smaller watersheds could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. Our study provides a framework for understanding the role of small streams in coastal eutrophication and highlights the need for watershed management efforts to address both large and small tributaries. This is especially important in the context of climate change, which is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network that is coupled to an environment that makes thermodynamic work available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the network dynamics are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This bias is particularly pronounced when the network is composed of a large number of distinct catalytic actors, each of which is able to access a small fraction of the environmental work. Our results suggest that the ability to access rare combinations of chemical concentrations may be a general feature of dissipative systems that are coupled to a rich environment.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs can change the intrinsic microcircuitry of the brain, which can predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. We validate a dynamic causal model of NMDAR-Ab effects on cortical microcircuitry and use this model to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes render microcircuitry critically susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms when these key parameters are changed, even though the same parameter fluctuations are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that the same mechanisms that underlie the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis may also underlie the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in other autoimmune encephalitis. This may help to explain the similarities between the two conditions. The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth system science. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood because of the difficulty in identifying and quantifying these events. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was associated with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that this event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon and to an increase in nutrient fluxes. These results provide insights into the history of abrupt climate change and the Earth system. (Show more)

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for reducing deforestation, but it is an important tool in the toolbox of conservationists and policymakers. We also show that the RSPO is not a panacea for tropical deforestation. The RSPO is a voluntary market-based scheme, and the effectiveness of certification depends on the actions of individual companies and countries. Our results suggest that certification is not a substitute for strong national policies and international commitments to reduce deforestation. We conclude that certification is a valuable tool for reducing tropical deforestation, but it is not a panacea.

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit complex that is essential for the final steps of exocytosis. It is involved in the regulation of vacuolar trafficking and the formation of the plasma membrane. The exocyst complex is conserved across kingdoms, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. Sex determination is a fundamental aspect of animal biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major area of study. In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes. In other vertebrates, sex is determined by multiple loci, resulting in multiple genotypic sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple sex determination loci in a cichlid fish, where two female-specific sex determination alleles interact to produce siblings with four possible sex classes. We find that multiple sex determination loci can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the introgression of a new sex determination allele can create additional axes of variation for secondary sexual characteristics. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of multiple sex determination alleles in populations. (Show more)

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoids, which are reactive intermediates that can photodegrade into damaging species. We show that the chelator deferiprone reduces the photodegradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the presence of light. This effect was mediated by a reduction in the levels of intracellular iron, which was in turn influenced by the levels of transferrin receptor, the receptor for iron-loaded transferrin. These findings suggest that iron levels impact the photodegradation of bisretinoids. This interpretation is supported by experiments showing that iron-reducing agents can protect retinal pigment epithelial cells from light-induced damage. This work provides insight into the role of iron in the photodegradation of retinal pigments. It also provides a rationale for the use of iron-reducing agents in the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystem functioning, and their evolutionary history is fundamental to understanding how food webs are structured. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered an evolutionary dead end. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic predators, can evolve into generalists, and that specialists on one prey type can evolve into specialists on other prey types. These findings help us understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also help us understand how specialization can be maintained in the face of competition for prey resources. This study contributes to the broader field of specialization and morphological evolution.

The human hand is a complex structure with a range of derived features that are shared with modern humans and Neandertals but absent in early hominins. These features are thought to have evolved to enhance the mechanical efficiency of the hand and to facilitate the use of stone tools. The evolution of these features is poorly understood because of a lack of fossil evidence from the time of their origin. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the origin of this feature and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human tool use. (Show more)

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and the mitochondrial isozyme is strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 blocks HCT-116 colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2. We show that formate generally rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. We show that defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a metabolic deficiency of cancer cells that can be targeted therapeutically. This work provides a rationale for the use of SHMT inhibitors in cancer therapy. The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. This study shows that natural landscapes such as forests can contribute to meeting both food and nutrition security goals. We found that deforestation led to a reduction in people’s fruit and vegetable consumption and thus vitamin A adequacy of their diets. Conversely, forest fragmentation led to an increase in fruit and vegetable consumption and dietary vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of considering the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals.

Modern farm machinery is a key driver of agricultural productivity, but it also causes soil compaction, which reduces soil porosity and affects soil ecological functioning. We show that the increase in mechanization has led to higher subsoil stresses, which now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
